subject: RE: [junit] Re: about teardown
msgSnippet: If you re overriding setUp(), it s a good idea to call super.setUp(). However, lately I ve not been doing that, simply because we haven t made any nested
messageBody:
If you're overriding setUp(), it's a good idea to call super.setUp().
However, lately I've not been doing that, simply because we haven't made
any 'nested' TestCase classes. This will come back to haunt us when we
do start simplifying tests by making base classes, for example, like a
DatabaseTestCase which does some sort of population and depopulation in
setUp() and tearDown().

I agree, however, if you don't really need it... Perhaps refactor it in
later... Don't really know, it is tough call.

If you do it right from the
start, then you will have no problems. Calling the
TestCase.setUp() and tearDown() methods will result in
a call that effectively does nothing, but is good for
laying groundwork for later on. YAGNI? Could
be...your call.

Guess it is matter of taste...

As far as overriding setUp() to avoid the base classes call...that is
untrue. You override it because it WILL be called before each test is
run, guaranteed.
Same goes for tearDown().

Which is why you want to override it yes?? If you don't, you get
default action which I believe is nothing... Perhaps, I wasn't clear in
the 1st post... Sorry.

Thanks,

--Ryan

--- Ryan P Ripley <ryan.ripley@...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> Correct me if I'm wrong, but you really only want to
> call [
> super.setUp() ]
> If you have extended a testcase the you have
> written?
>
> Example:
>
> public class testCaseB extends testCaseA {
>
> void setUp() { super.setup(); /** the rest of setup
> */}
> }
>
> As opposed to:
> In this case, I believe that the whole point of
> overriding setup() is to
> avoid the base class's [TestCase] implementation.
>
> public class testCaseA extends TestCase {
>
> void setup() { /** whatever you want to setup, no
> call to super */
> }
>
> This is how I understood this anyways, but then
> again, I am but a simple
> caveman. =))
>
> --Ryan
>
> - reset global state to the state before the test:
> Example:
> Object oldTool;
> protected void setUp() throws Exception {
> super.setUp();
> oldTool = Toolbox.getTool("ThreadFactory");
> Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",new
> TestThreadFactory());
> }
>
> protected void tearDown() throws Exception {
> Toolbox.registerTool("ThreadFactory",oldTool);
>
> }
>
>
> What are others doing in their tearDowns?
>
> Cheers,
>
> Arnd.
>
> BTW: Never forget to call the super setUp and
> tearDown!
>
>
>
>
